awd_titl_txt: Collaborative Research: Thermodynamics and Ion Transport in Hybrid Organic-Inorganic Block Copolymer Electrolytes
awd_abstract_narration:
NONTECHNICAL DESCRIPTION:

Life is increasingly intertwined with electrochemical energy storage, mainly in the form of lithium batteries.  They are integral to cellphones, laptops, scooters, electric vehicles, homes, solar installations, and even airplanes.  But these basic devices have potential safety hazards because they carry within a highly flammable liquid that has led to explosions and fires.  Building an intrinsically safe rechargeable lithium battery remains an unmet challenge, particularly in the development of a nonflammable electrolyte (the material that allows the flow of electrical charge in the battery) to replace the flammable organic liquid electrolyte in current lithium batteries.  Polymer electrolytes offer a promising alternative to the flammable liquid.  All previous studies have considered polymers made from organic building blocks.  The proposed work begins with a novel approach:  the synthesis of a hybrid polymer that comprises both organic and inorganic building blocks.  The polymer spontaneously forms 10-nanometer-wide alternating organic and inorganic layers (a human hair is 100,000 nanometers wide).  This material had very low flammability. The organic layers conduct the lithium ions while the inorganic layers provide mechanical rigidity to the polymer electrolyte, a property that is necessary to keep the two battery electrodes from touching and short-circuiting the battery.  The planned work examines the relationship between layer formation and lithium-ion motion through the composite electrolyte. The PIs collaborating on this project will also be working on diversity-related initiatives on the UC Berkeley campus, on organizing public lectures on scientific subjects aimed at high school students in Brooklyn, and  on providing multidisciplinary training to undergraduate and graduate students at their institutions.


TECHNICAL DESCRIPTION:

The proposed work focuses on mixtures of hybrid organic-inorganic block copolymers and a lithium salt.  Functionalized polyhedral oligomeric silsesquioxane (POSS) particles are covalently bonded to the inorganic block; the organic block is polyethylene oxide (PEO).  The hybrid block copolymers (PEO-POSS) will be synthesized using nitroxide-mediated radical polymerization with functionalized PEO as the macro-initiator.  Early results indicate that the phase behavior of pure PEO-POSS block copolymers is as expected: increasing temperature leads to an order-to-disorder transition. In contrast, salt-containing PEO-POSS mixtures exhibit a disorder-to-order transition with increasing temperature.  The effect of block ratio, chain length, and POSS functionality will be studied by a combination of depolarized light scattering, X-ray scattering, and electron tomography.  Measurements will be made over a wide range of block copolymer compositions, salt concentration, and annealing conditions.  The effect of morphology on ion transport will be measured by ac impedance spectroscopy.  The intellectual merit of the proposed work will be the study of the thermodynamic interactions and ion transport in an emerging class of hybrid nanostructured polymers comprising fully organic polymers and polymers with covalently-bonded inorganic nanoparticles; the present quantitative understanding of these properties is largely restricted to all-organic chains.

por.por_cntn:
Rechargeable lithium batteries have become an essential source of energy in modern society, powering our mobile phones, portable computers, bicycles and automobiles.  The safety and lifetime of such batteries depends on the nature of the material, called the electrolyte, that separates the battery's two electrodes and that conducts electric current inside the battery. 

We studied several different polymer systems as potential lithium battery electrolyte materials.  Polymers are long-chain molecules that make up such diverse materials as everyday plastics and biological proteins.  We studied a mixture of two polymers, polymethylmethacrylate (PMMA) and polyethylene oxide (PEO).  The first polymer, commonly called plexiglass, is a rigid polymer and gives the resulting electrolyte some rigidity.  The second polymer conducts lithium ions.  When these two polymers are mixed together with a lithium salt (LiTFSI) containing lithium ions, the mixture sometimes stays uniformly mixed, but sometimes the different polymers segregate to form separate regions called phases, depending on the relative amounts of the three different components.  If phase separation occurs, the electrolyte will not function properly.

We carried out a series of experiments to map out the fractions of PMMA, PEO and lithium salt at which this material forms a single phase or not.  Our collaborators at UC Berkeley worked out part of this map using neutron scattering (SANS), a very expensive technique that can only be performed at places like Oak Ridge National Laboratory, in which a beam of neutrons is directed at the material, and the deflection of the neutrons is measured.  We then expanded this map using light scattering, in which a beam of light is directed at the material and the deflection of the light is measured.  We measured two ways to quantify the deflection of light:  total forward scattered power and fraction of transmitted power.   We first studied the same samples studied by our collaborators, and discovered that for all the two-phase samples, the fraction of transmitted power was less than 1%, and for all the one-phase samples it was greater than 20%.   This gave us a criterion for determining the phase behavior of samples that had not been studied by neutron scattering.  Light scattering is a much simpler and less expensive method than neutron scattering and was carried out at our laboratory in Brooklyn. 

The results of our combined efforts are shown in Figure 1, a phase diagram for this system.  The x-axis is the concentration of salt, and the y-axis is the volume fraction of PEO.  The blue regions are single-phase regions where the components are mixed (miscible), and the red regions are where the components are phase-separated (immiscible).   The red region exhibits an unusual chimney shape, which is consistent with theoretical predictions, but has never before been observed experimentally.   

We also studied a polystyrene (PS)-polyethylene oxide (PEO) diblock copolymer, mixed with a lithium salt (LiTFSI).  In a diblock copolymer, each polymer molecule consists of two halves of different composition that are chemically bonded together.  In this case, half of the molecule is PS and the other half is PEO.  When such polymer materials are cooled below a critical temperature, they try to separate into two phases, but they can't, because the two components are bonded together.  Instead, they undergo a microphase separation resulting in micron-sized grains wherein each grain consists of nanometer-thick alternating layers of PS and PEO.  This grain structure can be probed using depolarized light scattering (DPLS), in which an x-polarized beam of light is directed into a sample, and deflected light with y-polarization is detected.  We then fit the resulting scattering pattern to the ellipsoidal grain model (EGM), which assumes that each grain is, on average, ellipsoidal in shape.  This fitting procedure allows us to extract an average grain width and length for a given sample.  The determination of the average grain size is important because it affects the mechanical, optical and electrical properties of block copolymer materials.

At the heart of the EGM model is a monotonically decaying function that describes the probability that two points are in the same grain, called the correlation function, C(r), where r is the distance between the two points.  If the two points are on top of the each other, then they are definitely in the same grain, which means C(0)=1.  If the two points are infinitely far apart, then they are definitely not in the same grain, which means C(infinity)=0.  The issue is how this function gets from 1 to 0 as r increases.  In past studies, we had assumed that is falls off according to a Gaussian function, exp(-kr2).  In this study, we explored to possibility that is falls off according to an exponential function, exp(-kr).  Although the mathematics was more complicated and required numerical integration, the resulting fits to experimental data were much better, as shown in Figure 2.
